courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Introduction to Sociology

meetings.location: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

courses.description: This course introduces basic concepts and principles in the field of sociology, helping students to make sense of their social life. Ideas such as social norms, social roles, social interactions, social institutions and social processes will be examined. This course also gives a brief introduction to major classical and contemporary sociological theories which explain how individuals and society are related to each other, especially how personal experiences are rooted in a particular social setting. Through these discussions, students should be able to think more critically towards a wide range of social issues and taken for granted social practices.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SOCI1102 or UGEC1823.

IV. Culture and Society
V. Socialization and Social Interaction
VI. Groups and Organizations
VII. Stratification and Mobility
VIII. Race and Inequality
IX. Sex and Gender

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Approaching Sociology
courses.description: Designed for major students new to sociology, this course serves as an extended introduction to sociology’s distinctive approach to the study of social life. It also aims at setting the foundation for the development of a variety of skills required for the study of discipline. It is also part of the Sociology Department’s academic mentorship programme that helps students better adjust to studying sociology, for example to learn to write better academic essay, and plan for themselves in their undergraduate years.
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) Familiarize with the sociological approach to social phenomena and the distinctive vocabulary and perspectives by which sociologists study them.
(2) Learn how to solve concrete self-directed research problems in a collaborative team setting and acquire first-hand experience in how social research is conducted.
(3) Become aware of the importance of a variety of study skills highlighted in the programme learning outcomes and the channels by which those skills could be developed in undergraduate studies.
(4) Better adjust to studying in the sociology programme in particular and plan for themselves in their undergraduate years.
(5) Be prepared to critically reflect on the role of AI tools and resources in their academic journey throughout university.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociology and Modern Society
courses.description: (UGEC1823 is double-coded with SOCI1102.) This course explores into the significance of sociological perspectives in understanding modern society. Attention will be given to the application of sociological concepts in the observation and analysis of social phenomena in modern society. The course is designed particularly to develop intellectual skills, as part of a student's general education, for a better understanding of the nature of modern society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SOCI1001 or UGEC1823.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- 
Students will gain exposure to a diverse set of sociological research, and understand how the relevant concepts and theories can be applied to modern societies.
- 
Students will develop an understanding of the constitutive relations between the economic, political, social, and cultural domains in society, thereby gaining a new perspective on their own lives and the world around them.
- 
Students will learn to develop their own analytical framework through active participation in discussion and completion of essay type test questions. These will enhance their general knowledge and skills in critical thinking.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Hong Kong Society: Identities and Boundaries
courses.description: From the “borrowed time and borrowed place”, Hong Kong has evolved into a global city with its own identity. Since the 1950s, the city experienced an economic miracle, withstood numerous financial crises, and is in the process of economic restructuring. Politically, it has turned from “the last Colony” of Great Britain into a Special Administrative Region of the PRC. Culturally, the flourishing Canto pop-culture coincides with the emergence of a local identity. Using a sociological perspective, this course critically reflects on the impact of these profound changes on the construction of the so-called ‘Hong Kong identity’. Who is a HongKongese? This seemingly simple question underlies critical issues and boundaries about nationality, ethnicity, language, culture, class, and citizenship. The construction of a Hong Kong identity necessitates the drawing of boundaries that include and exclude, defines who is entitled to resources and power and who is not, and projects differential expectations of rights and responsibilities on insiders and outsiders. The question thus has profound impacts on how resources and power are distributed in society, and affects the life chances of individuals, families and society.(Advisory: Not for Sociology Majors.)

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociology of Everyday Life
courses.description: This is a course on some essential dimensions of modern life including love, sex, work, public life, illness and death. To marry or not to marry? To die sooner or later? These are real choices for some people but irrelevant questions for many. Do we have freedom to lead a life of our own or has society already chosen the path of life for each of us? These are issues either taken for granted or deliberately avoided in our everyday life. In this course, sociological theories will be introduced to analyse how social institutions in the modern world have affected the meaning and pattern of life. Students are encouraged to have a reflective mind so as to contemplate what life style, or at least what attitude, we can choose regarding these dimensions of life.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGED2933 or SOCI2109.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Critical mind through sociological lens – to look some distance beyond the commonly accepted or officially defined goals of human actions after learning sociological concepts and theories.
2. Good observation – the ability to grasp the relationship between our individual lives and the larger social forces that help to shape them.
courses.course_syllabus:
Selected topics
1. Sociological perspective - "man in society" and "society in man".
2. Freedom and conformity in everyday life – “bad faith”, "escape from freedom" and possibility of freedom in everyday life.
3. Liquid love in post-modernity – art of loving in "love market" and "normal chaos of love" in post-modernity.
4. Work and corrosion of character and emotion – alineationa and deskilling in modern work; emotional labor in service society; corrosion of character in “flexible regime” of work in new capitalism.
5. Sickness, suffering and death in Everyday Life – social construction of pain and death.
6. Meaning of life – how different cultures and societies define the meaning of life.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Research Methods
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the fundamental principles and procedures of empirical research in sociology. Students will be presented with the theoretical and practical challenges involved in problem formulation, research design, data collection, and data analysis. We will examine some of the major types of both qualitative and quantitative social research methods (e.g., survey research, qualitative interviews, and ethnography) and the sampling, measurement and analysis issues involved with their use. We will also explore the ethical issues about conducting research in contemporary times. Students will be asked to conduct and report a basic research project involving either a quantitative or qualitative method.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of the course, students are expected to be able to:
(1) understand the logic of scientific inquiry and the steps in social research
(2) appreciate different approaches in conducting social research
(3) evaluate quality of a research project
(4) design a research project
(5) explore ethical issues about conducting research in contemporary times

courses.description: This course introduces the basic principles of statistical reasoning and its applications in social research. The objectives are to understand the basic assumptions of statistical methods and to interpret statistical findings in social surveys and experiments. Emphasis will be given to those descriptive and inferential methods that are frequently used for analyzing causal relationships among social variables and for testing social theories and hypotheses. The course will train students in analyzing social life and its changes.

5. To acquire hands-on knowledge on using statistical software to manage real socioeconomic data.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Development of Chinese Social Thought
courses.description: This course examines the origin, the transformation, and the characteristics of major Chinese thought in the past two millennia, so as to understand the sources of the values that guide the behaviour of Chinese people. The thought under examination include Confucianism, Legalism, Daoism, Moism, Liberalism, as well as different versions of Socialism. Methodologically speaking, this course will look at the structural forces that produce social thought and vice versa, rather than undue attention to particular times and events in history.
courses.learning_outcomes:
一、
通過與西方思想的對比，能夠描述中國社會思想的特點。
二、
能夠描述中國社會思想自春秋戰國時期至二十世紀九十年代的發展大勢，並指出每一發展階段的特點。
三、
能夠使用「挑戰與回應」（challenge and response）的理論視野，分析中國社會思想的形成和發展。
四、
能夠應用理性化過程（rationalization process）的「內在結構性緊張」（intrinsic structural strain）此一理論，分析現代中國社會思想的發展動力。
五、
通過傳統和現代的對比，能夠列舉思想在不同時代對維護既存體制和社會變革所扮演的不同角色。
六、
能夠列舉中國不同時代各派社會思想如儒家思想、法家思想、道家思想、墨家思想、保守主義、自由主義、社會主義的重心和特點。
七、
能夠分辨社會主義的幾個主要流派，即無政府主義、馬克思主義和民主社會主義。
八、
能夠認定社會思想的「存在基礎」（existential basis）。

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Japan in a Global Perspective
courses.description: The course examines the social and cultural dynamics of Japanese society. Emphasis will be given to the sociological implications of Japanese social organization and national identity especially as productions of a historical relationship with China and the West. Topics include: class and stratification, economic organization and work culture, marriage and the family, sex and gender, popular culture and everyday life, and the ideological system.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC2260 or GESC2160 or UGEC1232/JASP1100.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- To understand the importance of adopting an intellectual approach when studying an “other’s” culture within the context of a university general education programme
- To be able to differentiate a sociological perspective from a journalistic approach
- To consider some standards by which to assess the value of different explanations for the social and cultural dynamics of the Japanese society
- To be familiarized with the historical, social, political and cultural attributes of the Japanese society so that eventually an interdisciplinary approach can be appreciated
- To explore the expanding horizons in sociological explanations for the phenomenon of globalization in Japan, for example, a culturalist approach versus a world culture/polity perspective
- To develop transferable skills: collaborative learning, academic writing, and professional presentation
courses.course_syllabus:
Overview:
Current debates and discourse about Japan often point to the distinctive aspects of the social and cultural foundation of the country. The concern has been one that inclines to highlight the uniqueness of many of the country's internal attributes while ignoring the persistent dynamics inherent in Japan's involvement with the world. Hence, a proper approach to understanding Japan also requires our intellectual sensitivity to the interplay between local/national and global forces that shape the unique mode of development of the country. That is, we need to treat Japan not only as a "cultural artefact" but also as a social and political entity that finds its place in the world cultural evolution. The course attempts to fill this intellectual gap. By teaching Japan from a macro-sociological approach, the course seeks to address sociological inquiries and implications that are crucial to the understanding of some of the theoretical paradoxes of the Japanese society. Specifically, the course examines the social and cultural dynamics of Japanese society. Emphasis will be given to the sociological implications of Japanese social organization and national identity as productions of a historical and social relationship with her neighbouring countries and the world.
Some Distinct Characteristics of this Course:
· Adopting a sociological approach to understand and appreciate the social dynamics of institutional arrangements and changes in the Japanese society.
· Focusing not only on Japan’s national attributes, but also on the extent of global impact on the country's development.
· Use of tutorials to help students clarify concepts and theoretical perspectives. The tutorials will also facilitate students to work on their project assignments.
· Use of audio-visual materials (magazines, films and video) to help students understand better the lectures and reading materials
Topics Covered:
· Cultural Explanations and their Problems: a sociological approach
· Growing Up Modern in Japan: Socialization, Schooling and Education
· Coming of Age in Japan: Youth and Youth Culture
· Being an Adult Japanese: Social Responsibility, Work, and Marriage and Family
· Japan in a Comparative and Global Perspective: Convergent and Divergent Theories of Globalization

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociology and Hong Kong
courses.description: The objective of this course is to review and reflect on the efforts made by sociologists to understand the development of the Hong Kong society over the past half century. What is so special about Hong Kong? Why did it fascinate sociologists for so long in the post-war era? What had been the questions that caught their imagination? Has Hong Kong been falling out of the radar of sociologists? What do sociologists know about Hong Kong, and what more have to be done?
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SOCI1201, UGEC2865 or GEJC1020.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand and reflect on the contribution of sociology in the understanding of Hong Kong.
2. To master the dominant themes of sociological research on Hong Kong society.
3. To familiarize with and learn how to draw on the common primary and secondary sources of sociological research on Hong Kong society.
4. Integrating personal interests with existing research, to develop a personal agenda on the understanding of Hong Kong society.
5. To locate sociological research on Hong Kong from a developmental and comparative perspective.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Economic Reform and Social Impacts in China
courses.description: (UGEC2883 is double-coded with SOCI2106.)  Focusing on economic reforms, students will be taught the impetus of the institutional changes in China and how they affect the cultural, socioeconomic and organizational lives of Chinese people. Key social science concepts and theories like institution, ideology, socialism, marketization, social control, civil society, industrialization, urbanization, stratification, family, socialization, and specialized terms in China studies like guanxi (關係), danwei (單位), hukou (戶口), harmonious society, China dream, floating population, rural-urban divide, one/two child(ren) policy, will be introduced and discussed from an integrated perspective. After taking this course, students should be able to grasp the transformation and development in key areas of China, including economic reform, political system and change, rural and urban development, social inequality, family and marriage, cultural and ideological issues, as well as other institutional developments.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
SOCI2106 is double-coded with UGEC2883. 
Not for students who have taken GESC2118, UGEA2190 or UGEC2883.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Students are expected to grasp the basic knowledge about China’s major social institutions such as socialist market economy, party-state apparatus, stratification system, and lineage values. They should also be able to understand the evolution of these institutions over the past several decades.
• Students should be able to understand how social scientists analyze and examine the formation, evolution, and influences of the major social institutions in contemporary China. They are expected to grasp the key concepts and theories developed from social scientists from sociology, economics, political science, etc.
• Besides basic facts and social science perspectives, students are encouraged to critically evaluate some controversial topics from different angles through writing assignments. The topics will include key dilemmas in contemporary China regarding economic growth and social equality, state capacity and democracy, traditional culture and modernization, etc.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction: Basic Information of the Chinese Society
* Provide basic information about the socio-economic characteristics of the contemporary China.
Week 2 & 3: China before Reform Era
* Provide information about the political systems, economic institutions, and social control mechanisms of China during Mao’s era.
Week 4
& 5: Economic Reform
* Provide information about the processes of economic reform since 1978, as well as its impact on the economic system afterwards.
Week 6 & 7 & 8:
Impacts on the Political System and the Preservation of the Party-state
* Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the political system in China afterwards. Also, we will discuss the puzzle regarding the preservation of the Party-state despite the massive political reform.
Week 9
: Impacts on Rural-urban Development and Migration
* Provide information about the differential impact of the economic reform on the urban and rural development, as well as the resultant great migration since then.
Week 10: Impacts on Social Stratification and Inequality
* Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the transition of the social stratification system and the enlarging social inequality.
Week 11 & 12: Impacts on Social Conflicts, Civil Society, and Social Control
* Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the growing social conflicts and the newly emerged social control mechanisms.
Week 13: Impacts on Population and Demographic Transition
* Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the population and demographic patterns.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Criminals and the Law
courses.description: (UGEC2983 is double-coded with SOCI2116.)  Students enrolled in this cross-disciplinary course will address three basic questions: “why do people become criminals”, “who makes criminal law”, and “how is criminal law enforced”. Specifically, this course will include topics such as the social causes of criminal behaviour, the role of criminal law in social control, and the operation of the criminal justice system (their internal interaction and external interaction with other social organizations). Comparative and local empirical research will also be drawn to explore the crime problems and the development of criminal law and the criminal justice system in USA, PRC, Taiwan and Hong Kong. In addition, to strengthen the students’ understandings on the current criminal justice system, students will be given one field opportunity to directly experience police departments, courts or prisons in Hong Kong.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. 
To recognize major data sources, methodological approaches and issues in the study of crime, law and criminal justice;
2. 
To identify diverse patterns and types of crime in the United States, mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, and discuss their connection to processes of social change, social stratification and social control in the larger society;
3. 
To differentiate the major theories of crime, law and criminal justice
；
4. 
To
be able to apply
concepts and theories
in the student’s “hometown” community;
5. 
To demonstrate analytical and critical-thinking skills through the application of concepts and theories, as well as a broadened and more appreciative view of self and the society in which we live.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is an introduction of concepts and theories on crime, law and criminal justice system and their application to Chinese society. It will focus on how social structure and social policy could influence criminal behaviours and how society reacts to such behaviours.
1. Overview of Crime, Law and Justice: subject matters and key research questions
2. Types of crime, crime patterns, and crime statistics (official data, self-report data, and victimization data)
3. Organization of crime, such as fencing networks and black society
4. Social change and crime trends
5. Theories to explain crime: deterrence, rational choice, disorganization, anomie, social learning, social control, opportunity/routine activity, labelling, and conflict theory etc.
6. Classical Thoughts on Law and Society
7. Law-Making (state power and benefit groups; balance between liberty and public safety; penology) and Law-Processing (the role of law in social control; Paradigms and models of the criminal justice system)
8. Police: operation, theories and research
9. Courts: operation, theories and research
10. Correction: operation, theories and research

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Problems and Social Policy
courses.description: Both the objective conditions and the subjective definitions of social problems will be analysed in the context of social and economic development of society. The first emphasis of this course will be placed upon the application of basic sociological perspectives to the understanding of social issues and problems in Hong Kong and other societies. The second will examine the impact of sociological research of social problems on the formulation and improvement of social policy in response. The last emphasis will explore how sociological study of social problems are relevant to achieving UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students will be better able to: (a) look beyond common sense or public perception in understanding social problems in Hong Kong, (b) analyze social problems in Hong Kong from sociological perspectives, and (c) propose and draft policy responses to these social issues
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I. Theoretical framework
Introduction – What is social problem
? What is social policy?
Theorizing social problem I and II: Functionalist perspective and conflict perspective
Theorizing social problem III: Symbolic interactionist
perspective
Part II. Social problems and choices of policy responses
Gambling – Pathological habit or commodified risk? A public health model of gambling
Drug use – Risk society and the normalization of drug? Harm reduction versus abstinence policies
Sex work – Evolving perspectives on sex work? Decriminalization policies and reduction of public health risk
Part III. Tackling social inequalities
Social welfare policy: theoretical development and Hong Kong’s status
Poverty – Dependency culture or a lack of social capital? Ideological debate concerning anti-poverty policies
Racism – Why does racism exist? Who supports affirmative action policy? Some research evidence
Housing – from housing exclusion to the study of homelessness
Aging and ageism – What is ageism? Life-course perspective and active aging policy
Environmental problems and social inequalities – climate change as a global social problem
Course Structure
The course will consist of : (1) lectures, (2) tutorials, (3) field observation, (4) video presentation in a tutorial, and (4) a talk given by invited guests.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Urban Sociology
courses.description: Sociology has always had an intimate relationship with cities. Urbanization — the increase of the share of the population living in cities — was one of the developments that early sociologists sought to study and explain. Since then, the global urban population has only continued to increase. Today, over half of humanity lives in cities and towns. Understanding urban society is no less essential than in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Urban sociology has many sides, but in this course, students will learn about four main topics: 1) Early theories and classic statements on urban life, 2) the distinctive social character of the “urban experience,” 3) making sense of urban space in capitalism through various theoretical perspectives, and 4) the “hardware and software” of urban cities, addressing issues such as affordable housing, gentrification, creative class and minorities in the city.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able
to:
Describe the distinctive social character of the urban experience through urban ethnography
Analyze urban social phenomena and contemporary challenges through multiple theoretical frameworks and across different international contexts
Examine urban development patterns through both physical infrastructure and social dimensions with attention to local and global contexts

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Problems in China
courses.description: (UGEC2963 is double-coded with SOCI2216.)  China’s opening to the world has led to not only massive social and economic transformations, but also the emergence of social problems. This course explores some of these social problems, especially since the economic reform after 1978. The nature of these social problems and their possible causes will be critically examined, in the context of modernization, with the help of related concepts and theories in sociology. By the end of the course, students are expected to have a basic understanding of the major social problems in contemporary China and their implications for social and economic developments of China in the future.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC2963.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will be able to gain a basic intellectual understanding of the nature and possible causes of the major social problems faced by a changing China.
2. Students will be able to develop critical thinking on the public perception of social problems in China.
3. Students will be able to apply the theoretical perspectives and concepts gained from this course to analyze social problems they encounter in contemporary China.
courses.course_syllabus:
With the help of related concepts and theories in sociology, this course will critically examine the nature of some of the social problems and their possible causes faced by China under modernization. The topics include:
1. Theoretical approaches to social problems
2. Modernization and social problems in China
3. The evolution of the Communist Party and State since 1978
4. Rural problems
5. Urbanization and migration
6. Social inequality
7. Social resistance
8. Aging population
9. Crime trends and responses of criminal justice system
10. Environmental problems
11. Illicit Drugs and AIDS
12. Good/Bad Technology

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Marriage and Family
courses.description: This course discusses the major theoretical debates in sociology of marriage and family. Particularly, it looks at family structure and processes from various theoretical perspectives. Topics include major family transitions in adult life, such as love, mate selection, cohabitation, marriage, parenthood, divorce and remarriage. Special attention will be given to diversity of family forms, changing sex-role norms, class and childrearing practices, power and division of family labour, linkages between the family and the work systems. Whenever possible, family issues will be discussed and illustrated with examples in Chinese society.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Youth and Society: Issues in the Contemporary World
courses.description: This course explores some of the major issues concerning the role of the youth and the problems confronting them in modern society. The nature of the conventional wisdom of the “youth problem” is critically examined, with the help of concepts and theories in sociology and related fields. By the end of the course, students are expected to gain more understanding of the nature of the phenomenon of problematization of youth, and to look beyond common sense or public perception on current social issues related to the youth in modern society. More importantly, youth problems can jeopardize the sustainable development of youth. A broader and deeper understanding of various facets of problematization can inform how youth should be empowered to attain sustainable development in modern society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC2703.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To capture the extent of youth issues in modern society.
To demonstrate the ability to analyze complex youth problems through evaluating major arguments and evidence in the social studies of youth.
To critically assess how public perception of youth issues are shaped by social relations and institutions, patterns of social diversity and inequality, and processes that underpin social change and stability.
To reflect on students’ own life experiences as members of a younger population and their challenges of sustainable development in modern society.
To explore contemporary youth policy taking into consideration the dynamic local, national and global context.
courses.course_syllabus:
The core content of the course covers five areas in the study of youth issues.
The developmental discourse and the concept of social construction are examined to illustrate the emergence and the nature of the youth concept.
Biological, psychological and sociological views on the conceptualization of youth problem are introduced and compared, so as to illustrate the role and focus of social science, sociology in particular, in the study of youth problem.
Specific youth topics such as (1) education experience and inequality, (2) school-to-work transition, (3) generations and social mobility, (4) youth subculture, (5) gender and inequality, (6) love, intimacy and wellbeing, (7) sexual minorities, (8) digital lives and challenges, and (9) normalization of risk behaviors, are explored to scrutinize the forms and the extent of issues encountered by youth in modern society.
Sociological concepts and perspectives are
discussed to illuminate the social factors affecting the above-mentioned youth issues.
Postmodern perspectives and concepts will also be introduced to offer a discussion on the recent emergence of new forms of social transformation and crisis faced by youth.
The relevancy of topics and sustainable development goals (SDGs) are highlighted below:
Topic 1 Conceptualizing Youth
Topic 2 Conceptualization of Youth Problem
Topic 3 Education Experience and Inequality (SDG 4 Quality Education)
Topic 4 School-to-Work Transition (SDG8 Decent Work and Economic Growth)
Topic 5 Generation and Social Mobility (SDG1 No Poverty; SDG10 Reduced Inequalities)
Topic 6 Youth Subculture (SDG3 Good Health and Well-Being;
SDG16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions)
Topic 7 Gender and Inequality (SDG 5 Gender Equality)
Topic 8 Love, Intimacy and Wellbeing (SDG3 Good Health and Well-Being)
Topic 9 Sexual Minorities (SDG 5 Gender Equality)
Topic 10 Digital Lives and Challenges (SDG3 Good Health and Well-Being)
Topic 11 Youth in a Risk Society (SDG3 Good Health and Well-Being;
SDG16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions)
Topic 12 Conclusion: Citizenship and Belonging (SDG17 Partnerships for the Goals; SDG16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions)

courses.title: Introduction to Chinese Law and Society
courses.description: This course provides an overview of different topics in the fields of law and society, including judicial reforms, judges, courts, lawyers, litigants, civil justice, alternative dispute resolution, criminal justice, administrative justice, environmental justice, regulatory governance, law and technology, and transnational and international law. It will cover how empirical data are used to examine a theoretical concept. In addition to understanding the ideas in the readings, students are expected to explore the latest practices in a particular industry.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the main concepts of law & society: Grasp the key sociolegal concepts to understand actors, institutions, and procedures in contemporary Chinese judicial system. (LO1)
2. Apply sociolegal explanations of regulatory & compliance behaviours: Use sociolegal concepts to examine the private sector' compliance activities and the public sector’s regulatory governance practices. (LO2) And,
3. Contrive the latest practices based on empirical studies: develop some empirical study of the latest practices in a particular industry and provide with sociolegal explanations of such practices. (LO3)

courses.title: Organizations and Society
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to familiarize students with: (1) the nature, significance, issues and concepts of complex organizations in modern societies; (2) the approaches to, or the schools of thought on, organizational analysis; and (3) the structure and behaviour of complex organizations.

Students are expected to grasp the main theoretical perspectives in the sociology of organizations. They should understand the key concepts such as formal vs. informal structure, bureaucracy, incentives, teams, organizational culture, and institutions, among others.
They are expected to become familiar with the methodology of organizational research, including the quantitative and qualitative methods.
In addition, students are encouraged to apply what they learn in class to critically analyzing organizational phenomena they observe and solving organizational problems they encounter in real life.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Stratification
courses.description: This course discusses principles of allocation and reallocation of valuable social resources among different sectors of the population. Topics include fundamental concepts of social stratification, historical development of social inequality, classical and contemporary theories of class, social mobility, contradiction between equality and equity, implications of labour market segmentation and globalization on social equality.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Untitled Document
This course will review some of the classical and contemporary approaches to understanding the differential distribution of valued goods and the social processes. Students are encouraged to critically think of and discuss about six categories of questions as below:
(a) What are the major forms of stratification in human history? Is inequality an inevitable feature of human life?
(b) How many social classes are there? What are the principal? "fault lines" or social cleavages that define the class structure? Are these cleavages strengthening or weakening with the transition to advanced industrialism?
(c) How frequently do individuals cross occupational or class boundaries? Are educational degrees, social contacts, and "individual luck" important forces in matching individuals to jobs and class positions? What other social and institutional forces affect occupational attainment and allocation?
(d) How are the lifestyles, attitudes, and personalities of individuals shaped by their class locations? Are there identifiable "class cultures" in past and present societies?
(e) What types of social processes and state policies serve to maintain or alter racial, ethnic, and sex discrimination in labor markets? Have these forms of discrimination weakened or strengthened with the transition to advanced industrialism?
(f) Will stratification systems take on new and distinctive forms in the future? Is a "new class" of professionals and intellectuals emerging? Are the stratification systems of modern societies gradually shedding their distinctive features and converging towards some generic post-industrial or postmodern regime?

1. Introduction
2. Classical Theory on Class and Stratification: Marxist and Weberian Approaches
3. Contemporary Theory on Class and Stratification
4. Social Mobility
5. Education, Cultural Capital and Social Reproduction
6. Consumption Patterns and Cultural Distinction
7. Social Networks and Social Capital
8. Poverty and Underclass
9. Other Sources of Social Stratification
10. Conclusion

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Classical Sociological Theory
courses.description: This course explores the foundational works of classical sociological theory through the writings of Émile Durkheim (French, 1858-1917), Karl Marx (German, 1818-1883), and Max Weber (German, 1864-1920). Students will examine how these theorists addressed fundamental social issues and developed frameworks for analyzing social phenomena. The course emphasizes critical reading, analytical thinking, and understanding the historical context of sociological concepts. This course will explore the following questions: 1. What key themes and ideas emerge from classical sociological theory? 2. How does their social and intellectual context shape these ideas? 3. How can these theories inform our sociological way of questioning?
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
Explain the key ideas of major classical sociological theories and perspectives
Apply foundational concepts and frameworks of sociological theory
Examine historical and contemporary social issues from sociological perspectives
Evaluate critically theoretical arguments and their connections to empirical evidence

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Networks and Social Capital
courses.description: Social networks affect many aspects of our lives, and their effect persists over the life course. The science of social networks focuses on measuring, modeling, and understanding the different ways that people are connected to one another. In this course, we will use a broad toolkit of theories and methods drawn from the social, natural, and mathematical sciences to learn what a social network is, to understand how to work with social network data, and to illustrate some of the ways that social networks can be useful in theory and in practice. This course is designed to provide students with the opportunity to (i) master the major concepts within the field of social networks, with a particular attention to social capital theory; (ii) critically examine the causes and consequences of social networks across a variety of behavioral contexts and academic domains; and (iii) achieve minimum competency in social network analysis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC2013.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, you should be able to:
(1) Understand basic network concepts and theories, (2) Use social-scientific terminology to describe patterns of structure and change observed in networks, (3) Understand and be capable of using measures based on graph theory and matrix algebra to analyze and describe social networks, (4) Understand the way that social network concepts, theory, and measures can be applied to shed light on a wide variety of phenomena across different fields of study in the social sciences and beyond.

Economic sociologists examine economic life at all levels of analysis, including individuals, organizations, markets, fields, institutions, and states. Economic sociologists approach the study of economic life using diverse theoretical perspectives. This course will provide an overview of these broad concerns and approaches in economic sociology and review the sociological explanations of economic activities of production, consumption, investment, and compliance behaviors in various settings.

Contrive the latest innovative practices based on case studies of economic sociology: develop a socio-economic case study of the latest innovative practices in the private sector and provide with sociological explanations of their investment decisions and compliance behaviors. (LO3)

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Gender and Society
courses.description: This course takes up gender as the primary object of study and category of analysis. It aims to: 1) understand the conceptualization of sex and gender by various scholars and the implications of their theorization; 2) understand the process of becoming a woman/ man via the social construction of masculinity, femininity, sexuality and the body;3) understand the implications of being a woman/man on our lived experience, and the mechanisms that reproduce and maintain the observed gaps between the two sexes in daily lives or various institutions, e.g. family, education, and labour markets etc.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Introduction to Social Psychology
courses.description: The course introduces students to social psychology, a field that bridges the disciplines of sociology and psychology. With a sociological emphasis, the course focuses on the link and interrelationship between individual level and group level phenomena. It examines three main areas: (1) a person’s inner attributes, motives, and feelings, and how these are influenced by group and social forces; (2) interactions and interpersonal relationships among individuals; (3) group dynamics and social structures as emergent phenomena from individual and interpersonal processes.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Untitled Document
The course aims at achieving the following goals:
1. ) Motivate students to inquire into fundamental social phenomena or puzzles that we may have taken for granted, such as “why do humans cooperate?”
2. ) Guide students to learn the scientific approaches, including field work, experiments, and modeling, to answering the puzzles.
3. ) Encourage students to initiate a mini-project proposal to develop their own perspective, approach and method for a topic related to social psychology that they are interested in.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Contemporary Sociological Theory
courses.description: Most every sociology course on a specific domain of social life includes a discussion of the major theories proposed by sociologists in that specialty. This course is different. Here, students will learn not about theories of some specific sociological specialty, but instead contemporary sociological theories — period, full stop. What is offered by this course is an introduction to perspectives on society that link together the different facets of social life. These perspectives claim that the same insights can illuminate not just, say, education but also work and the family. They represent lens that can be used to view and understand these various social spheres, or they identify common trends that affect them. Students will gain from this course a deeper understanding of the most general questions asked by sociologists today, and which link together the more narrowly focused view of each individual study or subfield.We strongly encourage students to take SOCI3003 before taking this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To build skills in reading and discussing conceptually sophisticated arguments about society.
To acquire familiarity with the major theorists, theorists, and enduring questions of sociological theory in the past several decades.
To enhance the capacity to confront social life from a critical viewpoint through the application of theoretical perspectives to concrete examples.

courses.title: Democracy and Society
courses.description: This course investigates the relationships between society, culture and political system with emphasis on the social base of democracy. Topology of regimes, philosophical and institutional meanings of democracy, transition from totalitarianism or authoritarianism to democracy, the complex relationships between democracy and civil society, civic culture, economic development and other social factors will be discussed.

2. Research ability – students will need to conduct case study of an overseas democratic experience or system.
3. Presentation skills – students are required to make verbal report of their case study.
4. Ability to read books and apply knowledge.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Research Writing
courses.description: This course is designed to enhance the writing skills of sociology students so that they are more competent in meeting the writing needs of their discipline, especially in preparing adequate research-related papers such as proposals and reports. Students will learn such essential skills as writing effective sentences and coherent paragraphs, summarizing, paraphrasing, acknowledging sources and listing references, and understanding and describing data. They will study actual research papers to see how each main section is prepared in a proper academic style, and will practise writing paragraphs that represent the various sections of a research report.Advisory: For Sociology Majors only. courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociology and Films
courses.description: This course introduces students to the understanding of the motion picture industry in sociological perspectives. It will focus on the key theoretical approaches from sociology to the study of the media and culture, and show how they can be applied to empirical research on the film industry. It will draw on both academic research and a range of multimedia resources and illustrative materials, including media texts and video, to explore the changing role and constitution of the motion picture industry in contemporary societies.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Untitled Document
By the end of the course, students should be able to:
1) Demonstrate an all-round understanding of the relationships between film and society, and of the key theoretical debates and analytical approaches to the study of the media and culture in sociological perspectives.
2) Draw on the resources of sociological theory and empirical research in order to think creatively and critically about the ways in which the media and the cultural life of people are changing today.
3) Develop intellectual and research skills through critical engagement with the theoretical concepts drawn from the literature and also through analysing a range of empirical studies discussed in class.
courses.course_syllabus:
Untitled Document
Selected topics to be covered:
1) Introduction to sociology and films.
2) The Frankfurt School: The theory of the “culture industry” and its critiques.
3) The sociology of culture: “Arts worlds”, the “production of culture”, and the theory of “fields”.
4) Cultural imperialism and cultural hybridity.
5) The political economy perspective on the film industry.
6) Understanding receptions from culture and media audiences.
7) Motion pictures in the digital age: Sociological implications of “mediated communications” and the “mediatisation” of everyday life.
8) Case studies on the film industry in countries such as, United States, France, United Kingdom, India, Japan, South Korea, Singapore, China ,Taiwan, and Hong Kong

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Demography
courses.description: This course investigates social demographic phenomena in both structural and dynamic aspects. Causes and consequences of demographic trends at local, national and global levels will be examined. Subjects like population theories; determinants of population dynamics such as fertility, mortality and migration; and the integration of social and demographic theories will also be discussed.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Quantitative Data Analysis
courses.description: The focus of this course is on hands-on data analysis and the practical application of basic statistical methods to real-world social problems. Topics include causality, measurement, probability and statistical theory, regression models, analyses of network, textual, and spatial data. Particular attention will be paid to learning and implementing the R statistical program. Having taken Social Statistics (SOCI 2004 or equivalent elsewhere) and prior computing experience might be helpful but not required.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To master the logic of statistical analysis, with practical knowledge with a statistical program.
To rigorously apply statistical inference and estimation methods to real-world problems.
To be familiar with automated methods and visualization tools needed to identify patterns in network, textual, and spatial data or “big data.”
To be a keen reader and critical consumer of quantitative social science research.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Globalization and China
courses.description: In media coverage and many popular discussions on the topic, China features prominently as the “driver” of globalization or as the “workshop of the world”. Yet these simple observations leave much un-said. What is exactly meant by “globalization”? What is China’s experience of globalization? What are the political, cultural, and economic implications of living in an increasingly globalized world? Is China’s experience in this regard unique or similar to those of other countries? These are among the questions we will set out to explore in this course.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Qualitative Research
courses.description: This course aims to provide students with a foundation in the fundamental principles and procedures of empirical research in sociology. It will introduce various major types of qualitative research methods. Students will learn about various strategies for collecting (e.g. in-depth interview/focus group discussion, participant observation/ethnography, visual methods) and analyzing qualitative data (e.g. analyses of narrative, conversation and discourse, as well as grounded theory), They will also familiarize themselves with the ethical issues about conducting research in contemporary times.
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) understand the logic of scientific inquiry and the steps in social research
(2) describe and explain the essential characteristics of major qualitative research methods
(3) compare and evaluate the relative strengths and weaknesses of major qualitative research methods
(4) design and implement qualitative research project to address research questions
(5) evaluate quality of a qualitative research project
(6) reflect on the ethical issues related to qualitative research

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sexualities and Society
courses.description: This course critically explores how sexual desires, behaviors, and identities interact with larger cultural, social, economic and political forces. Throughout the course, it discusses how sexualities are bound up with struggles over citizenship, rights, entitlement and inequalities. As a whole, the course aims to open up space to debate how we may learn to live with ‘differences’ in an increasingly diverse world.
courses.course_syllabus:
Untitled Document
Course Syllabus
This course critically explores how sexual desires, behaviors, and identities interact with larger cultural, social, economic and political forces. The course involves discussions of sexualities at different levels, including sexual desires, behaviors, and identities (personal level), sexual norms, sexual cultures and sexual communities (community level) and regulations and laws governing sexualities (societal level).
We will debate how sexualities intersect with other social categories, such as class, age, race and ethnicity, in producing social structure. Throughout the course, it discusses sexualities are bound up with struggles over citizenship, rights, entitlement and inequalities. We also examine how social forces such as globalization, the internet, and medical technologies can reconfigure understanding and expression of sexualities.
The course aims to foster an interdisciplinary discussion, with Sociology as its core focus. It can involve controversial and at times emotionally as well as intellectually difficult readings and discussions. As a whole, the course aims to open up space to discuss and debate how we may learn to live with differences in an increasingly diverse world.
Topics to be covered:
1. Historical development of sexualities studies
2. Perspectives on sexualities
3. Sexual desires
4. Sexual behaviours
5. Sexual identities and communities
6. Social construction of sexualities
7. Intersectionality
8. Sexual inequalities and sexual citizenship
9. Sexual rights and struggles
10. Sex work
11. Diverse family forms
12. Sexualities: changes and continuities – globalization, the internet, and medical technologies
13. Concluding discussions

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Policing and Society: Critical Debates and Practices
courses.description: This course introduces the sociology of policing to students who wish to advance their understanding of the enforcement of law in a society. With a comparative perspective, the course examines institutions of police with regard to their role, function, organizational structures and culture in the contemporary world. Starting with a historical review of colonial policing in Hong Kong, the course unfolds gradually to reveal common policing issues and proceeds to assess the impact of transnational events like cross-border crime and global protest on local policing. Case studies of police practices in both local and global contexts are critically evaluated to identify the social forces that shape the respective social control process.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Untitled Document
At the end of this course students will be able to:
1. Comprehend the theories that underpin the development of policing systems in contemporary societies
2. Analyse the dominant forms of policing system worldwide with the ability to contrasts their merits and limits
3. Evaluate the interactions between the police and other social institutions and groups in a society
4. Recognize how global political and economic development challenge and influence policing systems and crime prevention strategies
5. Develop comparative perspectives towards policing practices
6. Appreciate the importance of sociology in contributing to the scientific and empirical study of policing

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Interaction and Video Analysis
courses.description: This course explores social phenomena that are so familiar they can escape our notice. Yet, they are highly organized and massively important to our lives. We will introduce the methodology of video analysis in sociology as a way to investigate social interaction in everyday life. Video analysis has been used to study a large variety of activities, for example, how people greet each other, how families eat together, how people taste cheese before buying, how skateboarders take turns in pool skate sessions, how people pass through doors, how tourists use Google maps to navigate through a city, and so on. The course is hands-on. You will be taught how to make your own video-recordings, as well as how to transcribe and analyse your data. There will be frequent in-class activities and discussions, so you are expected to be prepared and ready to contribute. Through your engagement in the course, you will gain an appreciation of the importance of real-time, observable behaviours for the accomplishment and maintenance of social interaction. You will also develop your powers of observation, attention to detail, and analytical skills.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- understanding the fundamental concepts of both ethnomethodology and conversation analysis
- ability to apply these fundamentals to the study of real-world settings to analyse the way in which the organisation of social settings is produced and reproduced through practical action
- ability to gather, transcribe, and analyse their own audio- or video-recorded data

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Migration and Policy Reflection on Global Citizenship
courses.description: Any consideration of global citizenship is incomplete without an examination of migration as part and parcel of the contemporary world. This course provides an introductory understanding of migration. To understand the operation of migration, we first discuss the general theories of immigrant adaptation. The theoretical framework for understanding migration ranges from the classic Chicago School to the recent institutional approach to migration. We then explore how the adaptation and survival strategies taken by immigrants. Policies governing migration and their impact on global citizenship are also discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken SOCI3453.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) to present an overview of the basic theories on migration,
2) to understand the operation of migration,
3) to evaluate how much the theories apply to the local, regional and global context, and
4) to reflect critically on the effects of current immigration policies in the context of global citizenship and to formulate action plans for facilitating migrants’ integration into the society.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Medical Sociology
courses.description: Health is a fundamental aspect of human existence and medicine is arguably the crown jewel of modern science. We all want good health, effective treatments of illness and affordable health care. Yet present-day health care is the flashpoint of many controversies: about the conflicts between patients and doctors; about the safety of medical treatments and reliability of medical knowledge; about inequality in health and longevity; and about the ever-increasing health care spending. This course dissects these issues from a sociological perspective. We ask questions such as: What counts as illness? How do people understand illness? How does illness affect people’s life? Who gets ill and why? What is the role of medical technology in fostering health? Why do doctors and patients have trouble communicating? How should health care systems be organized?
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC2003 or SOCI4207 (old code).
courses.learning_outcomes:
Untitled Document
1. Students are expected to learn to critically assess biomedicine from sociological perspectives.
2. Students are expected to gain insight into the constituent components of the healthcare system and the social and political factors related to the quality, cost and accessibility of healthcare.
3. Students are expected to learn to critically compare medicine to other social systems.
4. Students are expected to gain understanding of sociological theories from empirical examples in health and medicine.
5. Students are expected to learn to draw links between their daily experience and observation, and conceptual issues.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Digital Sociology
courses.description: Data and computational revolutions, coupled with the emergence of artificial intelligence (AI), have significantly impacted social life and request a new approach to the epistemic, methodological and normative issues of computational social science as an interdisciplinary field. This course introduces digital forms of research that advances theories of human behaviour by leveraging large-scale data from social media, dynamic networks, and real-time digitised and administrative records. This course also practices sociological imaginations to understand new social problems that we face in the age of big data and AI.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:
Describe the opportunities and challenges that the digital age creates for social research.
Use essential programming and computational techniques to analyse digital forms of social data.
Understand the logics behind large language models and artificial intelligence.
Practice sociological imaginations on the new social problems that we face in the age of big data and artificial intelligence.

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Environment and Society
courses.description: This course is designed to help students acquire fundamental knowledge and skills to examine and analyze the various environmental challenges in contemporary societies from a sociological perspective. Recognizing that environmental problems are often intricately connected with the conditions of societies that they are situated in, we will explore the processes underlying social and environmental changes as well as the consequences that those processes may entail at national, regional, and global levels. Substantive topics to be covered include limits of growth and development, sustainable production and consumption, climate change and global governance, and environmental movement. The course also aims to promote an awareness and understanding of the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) framework put forward by the United Nations in 2015 so as to facilitate a broader discussion and reflection on how individuals and societies can work together and find solutions to those environmental challenges.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Describe and explain the major sociological concepts, theories, and approaches that examine the relationship between environment and societal development
2. Identify and critically analyze the processes underlying social and environmental changes as well as the consequences that those processes may entail at national, regional, and global levels
3. Understand the United Nation’s framework of Sustainable Development Goals
4. Reflect on their own potential and capability to act in promoting sustainable development

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Social Studies of Science
courses.description: In the past decades, the world witnessed a sea change in the influence that scientific knowledge has in shaping the course of our economy and culture. From the development of iPhone to the Covid-19 vaccine, ours is a society organized around and even controlled by expert knowledge systems. Meanwhile, science itself also underwent increasingly fiercer attack by outsiders, a typical example being the disagreement on whether the climate change is real. Sociology of scientific knowledge offers us a set of tools to understanding and analyzing these heatedly debated big questions in society today. By critically analyzing science, scientists, and the system of knowledge production that they created and maintained, this course surveys major topics and recent developments in the social studies of science. The arrangement of these topics follows a micro-to-macro sequence: First, the course discusses personal level STEM experiences, such as STEM educational pipeline and STEM job market; then, the course discusses institutional and disciplinary level analysis of how science works and how innovations come about; lastly, the course moves on to society, national, and international level of the impact of science, using examples from the platform economy, the international politics and the global pandemic. By the end of the course, students will develop basic knowledge towards the Technology Facilitation Mechanism for supporting the Sustainable Development Goals, through critically examining the multistakeholder collaboration between scientific community, nation states and other stakeholders in the STI policy cycle.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. get familiar with major theoretical approaches in sociology of science and sociology of knowledge
2. understand what is a novel discovery in science, what defines a science discipline and what is interdisciplinarity
3. understand different forms of stratification in STEM pipeline, such as gender, race and global inequalities in becoming a star scientist / most innovative research team
4. critically reflect on the knowledge-based, skill-driven economy, with an emphasis on understanding the labor process in the gig economy and other data-intensive industrial sectors (i.e. software programming, AI)
5. critically reflect on the public mistrust in science during global crises, such as global warming and the Covid-19 pandemic
6. develop relevant knowledge towards the technology facilitation mechanism for supporting the Sustainable Development Goals

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Introduction to Global Sociology
courses.description: (UGEC3893 is double-coded with SOCI3241.) This course introduces undergraduate students to the knowledge world of global and transnational sociology, and the sociology of law, globalization and global governance, in which it will offer a guided entry into the complex ideas and writings of the sociological, political and legal scholars. The concepts they developed to analyze law, society and global governance are fundamental to address global and international concerns, including ESG (environmental, social & governance) investment, SDG (sustainable development goals), global climate change (Paris Agreement), global health (WHO), international economic, trade and monetary institutions (e.g., World Bank, WTO, IMF), global gender, children, labor and human rights systems (UNICEF, ILO, OHCHR), international law (ICJ) and international peace and security (UN Security Council). Upon completing this course, student will have critical understanding of the process in which UN intergovernmental bodies, states and non-governmental stakeholders coordinate at the inter-organizational and inter-institutional levels to implement the UN 2030 Agenda, and respond to the challenges within.

Question: Who controls the World Bank and the IMF? What is the difference between the British and American Empires? And, why do the World Bank and IMF matter to an international financial hub like London, New York or Hong Kong?

Question: who manages the global financial system? What is a financial crisis? And, how did it impact on international financial hubs like London, New York or Hong Kong?

Question: What is the meaning of a free port? Why is it so important for Hong Kong to keep a free port trade policy? How did the US-China trade wars occur? What is the impact of the US-China trade wars on Hong Kong?

meetings.location: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE
Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE
Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

courses.description: To Sutherland and Cressey, criminology is the body of knowledge regarding crime as social phenomena, which encompasses the process of making laws, breaking laws, and reacting to the breaking of laws. With a comparative perspective, this course focuses on how governments and law enforcement agencies in different societies intervene in the breaking of laws in a globalized world. The course begins by introducing various concepts of social control from a sociological standpoint. In addition to a review of the relevant criminological theories and empirical research findings, the course assesses the major impact of globalization on public security and explores the proliferation of transnational criminal activities in the process. Finally, the course will examine how social control agencies react and seek to address these problems in local and global context.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, the students are expected to:
have acquired a good knowledge on how criminological theories can help them to understand the relationship between crime and social control
understand the risks and challenges posed to public security in different societies by the process of globalization
recognize how some social control measures are conducted locally and in overseas to combat against crimes
be able to apply sociological perspectives and insights to review and assess the effectiveness of social control measures in different jurisdictions

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Generalized Experimental Methods for Social Research
courses.description: This course is a nontechnical introduction to the intellectual and methodological developments that undergird the exciting new era of social research using randomized experimental and quasi-experimental designs. Through in-depth case studies of exemplary empirical studies based on randomized experimental/quasi-experimental designs, the course will demonstrate how basic research could help understand human attitudes/perceptions/behaviors and provide evidence-based guidance for policymaking.This course is intended for students in their third or fourth year of college. The course coverage will be helpful to students who intend to pursue more advanced academic training, government sector jobs that place a premium on program evaluation and quantitative literacy, or service industry jobs that have witnessed a surging demand for big data applications. A one-term course on basic statistics is essential for understanding the technical but elementary terms used in this course. Still, math and statistical skills are not required to excel in this course.Specifically, the course is designed to achieve three learning objectives:1. To master the generalized experimental methodology by studying the core principles of experimental designs and some exemplary social science experimental studies. 2. To ask real-world questions that can be answered with randomized experiments (of various forms) to understand human perceptions/behaviors, induce behavioral changes, and inform evidence-based policymaking.3. To gain intuitive understanding of the counterfactual paradigm for causal thinking (i.e., using quasi-experimental designs) when truly randomized experiments are infeasible.Evaluation of learning progress and performance will closely align with the course objectives. The course assessments would emphasize the conceptual and empirical understandings of experimental designs and their real-world applications through a group project presentation and a short research proposal written by individuals. The primary language of instruction, teaching materials, and students’ written submissions will be in English.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To master the generalized experimental methodology by studying the core principles of experimental designs and some exemplary social science experimental studies.
To ask real-world questions that can be answered with randomized experiments (of various forms) to understand human perceptions/behaviors, induce behavioral changes, and inform evidence-based policymaking.
To gain intuitive understanding of the counterfactual paradigm for causal thinking (i.e., using quasi-experimental designs) when truly randomized experiments are infeasible.

Introduction
Experimental thinking: What are experiments; how to use them to address real social issues and inform policy debates; core principles of experimental designs
Randomized experiments:
Different types of randomized experiments: field experiments, lab experiments, and online experiments, etc. (provided with research exemplars) I
Different types of randomized experiments: field experiments, lab experiments, and online experiments, etc. (provided with research exemplars) II
Different types of randomized experiments: field experiments, lab experiments, and online experiments, etc. (provided with research exemplars) III
The synergies between experiments and traditional surveys
When experiments meet public policy interventions
When experiments meet behavioral science: conducting experiments in the digital age
Leveraging AI in experimental research
What can we do when classical randomized experiments are infeasible?
Quasi-experiments: What it is and is not; the pitfalls of social experiments.
Weighting techniques as a statistical approach to emulate an experiment.
Matching techniques
Instrumental variables
Regression discontinuity designs
Asking Your Questions and Designing Your Experiments
Group presentations

courses.description: Having access to adequate housing is a basic human right under Article 25 of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights (1948). Housing not only satisfies ontological needs but also plays a critical role in social stability and individual well-being. Decades later, housing problems in both local and overseas societies remain acute. However, we now have a better understanding of the social causes and consequences of these issues through years of empirical research and studies, hence with potential ways to achieve more sustainable housing. This course examines housing from a broad social science perspective while providing students with a solid foundation in the sociological understanding of housing. The course begins with a review of the literature, exploring the political economy of housing production and consumption. Key topics include: An examination of the various agents involved in the housing market, including tenants, landlords, urban planners, and developers. Reflections on the social construction of the meaning of housing and its implications for individuals and communities. A discussion on the financialization of the housing market and the unequal accessibility of mortgage credits, which shape life chances and create new forms of inequality in urban centers. The impact of living in substandard housing on health and psychological well-being. Issues of housing segregation along ethnic and racial lines, gentrification, displacement, and homelessness. The complex relationship between housing and welfare policy. Through this comprehensive examination, students will gain insights into the multifaceted nature of housing issues and the critical role of sociology in studying them.
courses.learning_outcomes:
L1 – To critically understand housing rights from social science perspectives
L2 – To analyse the housing markets and inequalities from comparative perspectives
L3 – To evaluate housing’s social impact on individuals and communities based on empirical studies
L4 – To examine sustainable housing policy and its complex relationship with welfare governance
L5 – To reflect on one’s value position and develop advocacy skills

courses.subject: SOCI
courses.title: Sociology Field Studies
courses.description: The Sociology Field Studies provides students with an opportunity to apply sociological theories and methodologies in real-world contexts through experiential learning. Conducted by faculty from the Sociology Programme, this course focuses on the exploration of social issues and cultural dynamics in various environments outside of Hong Kong.Students will engage with diverse communities, enhancing their understanding of social structures and cultural practices in different contexts. The course encourages students to conduct comparative studies across different societies, promoting critical thinking about sociological concepts and their application. Students will interact with local scholars/university students and/or community members, fostering cross-cultural dialogue and collaborative learning experiences. A study trip to a selected destination outside of Hong Kong will take place during term breaks, providing immersive experiences in the field. Students will be required to engage actively in all course activities, including lectures, workshops, and field studies. The assessment will include individual and group-based assignments, culminating in a reflective report that integrates their field experiences with sociological theories. By the end of the course, students will have developed practical skills in sociological research and analysis, enhancing their capacity to engage meaningfully with global social issues and contributing to their growth as informed global citizens.
courses.learning_outcomes:
L1: Application of Sociological Theories: Students will demonstrate the ability to apply sociological theories and methodologies to analyze social issues and cultural dynamics encountered in diverse communities.
L2: Comparative Analysis Skills: Students will develop critical thinking skills to conduct comparative analysis across different societies, enhancing their understanding of social structures and cultural practices.
L3: Cross-Cultural Engagement: Students will effectively engage with local scholars, university students, and community members, fostering cross-cultural dialogue and collaborative learning experiences.
L4: Reflective Practice: Students will produce reflective reports that integrate their field experiences with social science perspectives, demonstrating their capacity to connect theoretical knowledge with real-world social issues and enhancing their growth as informed global citizens.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course consists of three components: pre-trip lectures/workshops, a field study tour outside Hong Kong, and post-trip sharing sessions. These elements are designed to provide a comprehensive learning experience, allowing students to engage deeply with sociological concepts in real-world contexts.
Pre-trip Lectures/Workshops (minimum two days or four three-hour sessions)
Participants will attend two days of lectures and workshops that provide essential background information and relevant sociological knowledge. These sessions will prepare students for the field study by equipping them with theoretical frameworks and critical tools necessary for analyzing social dynamics in the selected region.
Field Study Tour (minimum three days)
Following the pre-trip sessions, students will participate in a study tour to a major city outside Hong Kong. The study tour will last for a minimum three days. This immersive experience will involve onsite visits to various sites, allowing participants to observe and consolidate their knowledge of the social structures and cultural practices in the area.
Post-trip Lectures/Workshops (one day or two three-hour sessions)
A post-trip workshop will be held to facilitate student sharing of observations and findings from their experiential learning. The course instructor will guide discussions and reflections, helping students to integrate their field experiences with sociological theories and concepts. This reflective process aims to deepen understanding and enhance critical thinking about the issues explored during the tour.
